qas.question: J.S. Bach's fugues create a coherent harmonic logic that would be impossible for what other style of music?
The score determines how various parts are coordinated, pitch, and what other detail?
What has allowed Classical musicians to perform music from many centuries ago?
Who's fugues achieve a remarkable marriage of boldly distinctive melodic lines?

context: The key characteristic of classical music that distinguishes it from popular music and folk music is that the repertoire tends to be written down in musical notation, creating a musical part or score. This score typically determines details of <a1_0>rhythm<a1_0/>, pitch, and, where two or more musicians (whether singers or instrumentalists) are involved, how the various parts are coordinated. The written quality of the music has enabled a high level of complexity within them: <a3_0>J.S. Bach's<a3_0/> fugues, for instance, achieve a remarkable marriage of boldly distinctive melodic lines weaving in counterpoint yet creating a coherent harmonic logic that would be impossible in the heat of <a0_0>live improvisation<a0_0/>. The use of <a2_0>written notation<a2_0/> also preserves a record of the works and enables Classical musicians to perform music from many centuries ago. Musical notation enables 2000s-era performers to sing a choral work from the 1300s Renaissance era or a 1700s Baroque concerto with many of the features of the music (the melodies, lyrics, forms, and rhythms) being reproduced.
